quote: Jesus said, 'Receive your sight; your faith has healed you.'
firstReading: No first reading text was provided for this entry. In the context of today's observance, the lectionary emphasis falls on the Gospel account of Jesus restoring sight to the blind man. Where a first reading is used in the liturgy, it typically prepares the assembly by presenting Old Testament testimony to God’s saving action; here the available materials invite reflection primarily on faith, healing, and discipleship found in the Gospel.
psalmSummary: The selected verses from Psalm 119 portray fidelity to God’s law amid persecution and distress. The psalmist confesses suffering at the hands of the wicked, yet refuses to forget God’s statutes. There is a plea for rescue and grace, a confidence that salvation is distant for those who ignore God’s commands, and a firm commitment to the rightness of divine precepts even in trials.
gospelSummary: In Luke’s brief narrative a blind man sitting by the roadside near Jericho cries out as Jesus passes, identifying him with the promised Davidic deliverer. The crowd initially rebukes him, but he persists, and Jesus calls him forward. Asked what he wants, the man plainly asks for sight. Jesus heals him, attributing the restoration to the man’s faith. Immediately the man receives his sight and follows Jesus, praising God—an act of discipleship that highlights both personal faith and public witness.
saintReflection: St. Elizabeth of Hungary (Memorial): Princess Elizabeth (1207-1231) was renowned for her deep compassion for the poor, giving away her possessions and founding hospitals. Canonized for her mercy and devotion as a widow.
dailyPrayer: Lord Jesus, who stopped on the road to bend down to the poor and the blind, grant us eyes to see and hearts to act. Increase our faith so that we may call to you without shame and follow you without delay. As you healed the blind man and made him a witness, make us instruments of your mercy. Inspire in us the generous charity of St. Elizabeth of Hungary: let our possessions serve the needs of the poor, our time provide comfort to the afflicted, and our lives bear public witness to your love. Teach us to defend your law with humility, to trust your rescue in distress, and to praise you in every healing. Amen.
theologicalSynthesis: The readings present a unity of faith, law, and mercy. Psalm 119 insists on fidelity to God’s statutes amid persecution, while the Gospel narrates a faith that obtains sight and leads to discipleship. The healed man’s persistent cry and Jesus’ response show that God’s law and compassion are not opposed: obedience to God’s will is expressed through trust in God’s saving action. St. Elizabeth embodies this synthesis, living a faith that serves the poor. The Christian vocation is therefore both hearing God’s word and enacting God’s mercy in concrete service.
exegesis:
Context: Luke places this healing near Jericho on his journey to Jerusalem, a sequence populated by teachings on discipleship, prayer, and the coming of the kingdom. The narrative economy is tight: a single miracle episode becomes a summary of Luke’s larger concerns—reception of Jesus as the Davidic savior, the primacy of faith, and the social consequences of encounter with him. The crowd’s initial rebuke and the blind man’s persistence highlight the barrier between public opinion and personal faith.

Psalm: The clustered verses from Psalm 119 reflect the faithful’s struggle under hostility. The psalmist experiences suffering because of the wicked yet clings to God’s law as a lifeline. Requests for rescue and declarations of adherence to right precepts show a spirituality that combines lament with trust. This tone prepares the heart for a Gospel scene where trust—rather than social standing or rhetorical skill—becomes the avenue of salvation.

Gospel: Luke’s account compresses action and theology. The blind man’s cry identifies Jesus with messianic hope, and his persistence models the posture Jesus commends. Jesus’ question and the man’s candid request turn the encounter into a moral exchange: the man articulates need; Jesus responds with restorative power, which he links to faith. The immediate result is not only physical healing but a conversion to following Jesus, illustrating that miraculous restoration in Luke serves the call to discipleship.

Saints: St. Elizabeth of Hungary incarnates the Gospel’s ethic. Her life shows that faith which receives God’s mercy must become mercy toward others. Where the healed man’s sight leads him to follow and praise, Elizabeth’s compassion led her to reallocate wealth for the welfare of the sick and destitute. The saint’s example provides the church with a model for translating private faith into public charity; her canonization recognizes that holiness is measured in acts of service as well as interior devotion.

Today: For contemporary believers these texts pose urgent questions. Do we persist in calling to Christ when social pressures discourage faith? Do we maintain fidelity to God’s commandments while actively serving those in need? The readings invite Christians to combine legal fidelity and merciful action: to keep God’s statutes as a moral horizon while imitating Christ’s readiness to heal and restore. Practically, this means advocating for the vulnerable, welcoming the marginalized, and allowing personal transformation to produce communal compassion.
